---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

- [x] depends on: #8700 [That PR breaks this one]

nodes.body:
maintainer merge

I pushed some cleanups, so someone should give this a final look over
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by eric-wieser.

This PR will probably need to wait, I just noticed the std bump in #8700 changes a lot of the BitVector definitions and breaks some of the trivial proofs `rfl` here. Since #8700 seems to be higher priority, I propose we wait until that has been merged, then fix this PR.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#8700~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
#8700 has been merged, and this PR fixed accordingly, so it is once more ready for review!
I guess this may have fallen from the maintainer queue due to @alexkeizer cancelling the merge. @semorrison, any chance you could have a brief look?

:v: alexkeizer can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+
Thanks for the quick final review @eric-wieser!

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7224604503/job/19686247373)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7224604503/job/19686247006)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7224604503/job/19686246377)

bors d+

Thanks!
These lemmas look backwards to me; I'd expect simp to push `ofFin` to the inside to turn things into a statement about `bitVec`.
(if the user wanted to work with `Fin` instead, then they could apply `toFin_injective`, and push `toFin` to the inside in the same way).

My reason for the direction is that `ofFin x &&& ofFin y` unfolds to `ofFin <| (ofFin x).toFin &&& (ofFin y).toFin`, where `(ofFin x).toFin = x`. So, the `Fin` expression is (in my mind) simpler / more fundamental. Turning that aroung seems to me not something we'd want `simp` to do by default.

I'll concede that I often forgot how useful `toFin_injective` can be, but it cannot always be used. For example, for inequalities or in subexpressions. Then again, in my current use-case it can, so I'm more than happy to leave these theorems out if you insist they are not desirable
I'd prefer that we keep the *reverse* of these theorems; they match things like `MulOpposite.op_add` etc.
I think it would be better to use `Function.Injective.commRing`.

That seems cleaner, yes. However, `Function.Injective.commRing` requires instances of `[SMul ℕ β] [SMul ℤ β] [Pow β ℕ]`, which `CommRing` by itself does not need.
Is this by design, it seems `Function.Injective.commRing` shouldn't need them if it's just defining an instance of `CommRing`?

> which CommRing by itself does not need.

Actually it does need them, but it generates them automatically if you forget them.
The point here is that probably you don't want the auto-generated ones; the manual implementations in terms of `Fin` will likely have better properties.

nit: I'd put these before the `toNat` ones, as they're in some sense more fundamental. You could also then replace the proof of `Function.Injective (@Std.BitVec.toNat n)` with `toFin_injective.comp Fin.val_injective` or similar if you wanted, not that it really matters.

These names aren't quite right:
```suggestion
@[simp] lemma ofFin_neg (x : Fin (2^w)) : ofFin (-x) = -(ofFin x) := by
  rw [neg_eq_zero_sub]; rfl

@[simp] lemma ofFin_and (x y : Fin (2^w)) : ofFin (x &&& y) = ofFin x &&& ofFin y := rfl
@[simp] lemma ofFin_or  (x y : Fin (2^w)) : ofFin (x ||| y) = ofFin x ||| ofFin y := rfl
@[simp] lemma ofFin_xor (x y : Fin (2^w)) : ofFin (x ^^^ y) = ofFin x ^^^ ofFin y := rfl
@[simp] lemma ofFin_add (x y : Fin (2^w)) : ofFin (x + y)   = ofFin x + ofFin y   := rfl
@[simp] lemma ofFin_sub (x y : Fin (2^w)) : ofFin (x - y)   = ofFin x - ofFin y   := rfl
@[simp] lemma ofFin_mul (x y : Fin (2^w)) : ofFin (x * y)   = ofFin x * ofFin y   := rfl
```

```suggestion
## Distributivity of `Std.BitVec.toFin`
```
so that this is linked in the docs.

I'd recommend 
```suggestion
  smul x y := .ofFin (x • y.toFin)
```
and similarly below.

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma ofFin_zero : ofFin 0 = 0 := rfl
@[simp] lemma ofFin_one : ofFin 1 = 1 := rfl
```
though these probably belong in the section above.
rather than `intros; try rfl`, can you use the names of the lemmas that you already created above? It's a nice check that you wrote all the ones that matter.
I guess these two shouldn't be `simp`

A nicer way to write this is
```suggestion
@[simp] lemma toFin_zero    : toFin (0 : BitVec w) = 0 := rfl
```
This looks like a bad choice of simp lemma by std, so I'd be inclined to leave a TODO comment (after removing `simp`)

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma toFin_natCast : toFin (n : BitVector w) = n              := rfl
```
To avoid needing the `@`
Can you add the `OfNat` lemma too? It will probably need to be after the ring instance
I added these myself
Thanks!
Using `.ofInt` probably is the right thing to do, since ultimately `ofInt` is likely to be more efficient.
Fair point, I've redefined `IntCast` and proven the necessary equivalence with `Fin`s `IntCast` instance
Do you have any opinions on leanprover/std4#415? That will almost certainly break this proof, so it probably makes sense for you to review it (and maybe wait for a merge) before merging this.

It's not immediately obvious to me that your version indeed is faster, but otherwise that PR LGTM.

I would prefer we merge this one sooner rather than later, though, since the various `toFin_` and `ofFin_` lemmas are also useful for further developments. Would it be a problem to just merge this now, and fix the proof in the std bump PR once leanprover/std4#415 gets merged? 
Alternatively, I can replace this proof with a `proof_wanted`, comment out whatever depends on it (i.e., the `CommRing` instance), and factor those out to a new PR, so that at least the other lemmas are available.
https://github.com/leanprover/std4/pull/415 is now merged into master. I rebased this PR on master, such that we now can rework this proof.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ← Nat.sub_sub ```
Perhaps it makes sense to reduce this PR to the `CommSemiring` case to get it merged, and then come back and prove the necessary things for `CommRing` about `ofInt` later?
Agreed, I've parked the attempt at a proof I did earlier in the `bitvec-ring2` branch, and reduced this PR as suggested
Can you open a new WIP PR from that branch so that it doesn't get forgotten?
I think this instance is already defined by Std? Maybe I'm mistaken

These are all the instances that are defined in https://github.com/leanprover/std4/commit/fa17cba0459830906e99f0a81fb0edc106220380:

```bash
grep -R instance Std/Data/BitVec
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : Inhabited (BitVec n) where default := .zero n
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : OfNat (BitVec n) i where ofNat := .ofNat n i
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : Repr (BitVec n) where reprPrec a _ := "0x" ++ (a.toHex : Format) ++ "#" ++ repr n
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : ToString (BitVec n) where toString a := toString (repr a)
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : Add (BitVec n) := ⟨BitVec.add⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : Sub (BitVec n) := ⟨BitVec.sub⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : Neg (BitVec n) := ⟨.neg⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : Mul (BitVec n) := ⟨.mul⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : Div (BitVec n) := ⟨.udiv⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : Mod (BitVec n) := ⟨.umod⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : LT (BitVec n) where lt x y := x.toFin < y.toFin
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : LE (BitVec n) where le x y := x.toFin ≤ y.toFin
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : AndOp (BitVec w) := ⟨.and⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : OrOp (BitVec w) := ⟨.or⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : Xor (BitVec w) := ⟨.xor⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : Complement (BitVec w) := ⟨.not⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : HShiftLeft (BitVec w) Nat (BitVec w) := ⟨.shiftLeft⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : HShiftRight (BitVec w) Nat (BitVec w) := ⟨.ushiftRight⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance {n} : HShiftLeft  (BitVec m) (BitVec n) (BitVec m) := ⟨fun x y => x <<< y.toNat⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance {n} : HShiftRight (BitVec m) (BitVec n) (BitVec m) := ⟨fun x y => x >>> y.toNat⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : HAppend (BitVec w) (BitVec v) (BitVec (w + v)) := ⟨.append⟩
Std/Data/BitVec/Basic.lean:instance : Subsingleton (BitVec 0) where
```

I do not see NatCast.
I've confirmed with `#synth` that the instances at the least don't exist in the files imported at that point, which includes `Std.Data.BitVec`, so I'm pretty sure they don't exist in Std at all

```suggestion
-- TODO: generalize to `CommRing` after `ofFin_intCast` is proven
```
Perhaps worth a comment that either of these follows trivially from the other (though that doesn't help with deciding which one to prove)
Done.
This lemma looks quite strange to me; I think it would be best left to a later PR
Dropped.

```suggestion
-- Either of these follows trivially from the other. Which one to
-- prove is not yet clear.
```
I don't see any uses of `linarith` in this file.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: show that `BitVec` is a commutative ring
